article.description:
Hollis Price and Quannas White each scored 19 points as No. 5 Oklahoma built a 32-point second-half lead and
then held on to beat No. 6 Kansas 77-70 Sunday.

related.description: Oklahoma has figured out how to use lanky center Jabahri Brown. The rest of the country better watch out, Andy Katz writes.
related.linkText: Katz: A lanky non-center center has Sooners excited
related.title: With Brown in the flow, Sooners are for real
related.headline: With Brown in the flow, Sooners are for real

article.headline: Sooners' home streak alive, so are Big 12 title hopes
article.linkText: Sooners don't quite blow 32-point lead vs. Kansas
article.story:
NORMAN, Okla. (AP) -- Hollis Price and Quannas White each scored
19 points as No. 5 Oklahoma built a 32-point second-half lead and
then held on to beat No. 6 Kansas 77-70 Sunday.

	   The Sooners (19-4, 10-2) moved into a first-place tie with
Kansas in the Big 12 and extended their homecourt winning streak to
36 games, longest in the nation.

	   Kansas (20-6, 10-2) got 21 points from Kirk Hinrich and 15
points and 14 rebounds from Nick Collison, but couldn't overcome an
awful start. The Jayhawks trailed by 21 points at halftime and by
59-27 with four minutes into the second half before getting as
close as five in the final minute.

	   The record for biggest deficit overcome to win a game is 32
points by Duke against Tulane on Dec. 30, 1950. The Blue Devils
were down 54-22 late in the first half before winning 74-72.

	   Price came up with one of Sunday's biggest shots, a leaner over
Hinrich that stopped a 7-0 Kansas run and gave Oklahoma a 72-61
lead with 2:13 to play.

	   Price later missed two free throws -- he had made 36 in a row
before that -- and White missed two with 54 seconds left and
Oklahoma leading 72-66.

	   Collison, who was just 5-of-18 from the field, missed from in
close with 42 seconds left and the Jayhawks turned it over six
seconds later. White followed with a free throw for a 73-66 lead,
and a shot by Collison with 23 seconds remaining was as close as
Kansas got.

	   Kansas, the last team to win in Norman, wound up shooting just
34 percent (21-of-61).

	   The Sooners took control early by hitting their shots and
controlling the backboards at both ends of the floor. White had
three 3-pointers and Price had two as Oklahoma went 6-of-10 from
behind the arc in the first half.

	   The Sooners had a 10-3 lead in the first five minutes, stretched
it to 17-6 with 11:30 remaining and went on to lead by as many as
21.

	   Oklahoma center Jabahri Brown was an early surprise on offense,
scoring seven of the Sooners' first 12 points. He also had two
blocks before getting shaken up at the 10:15 mark and leaving the
game.

	   Kansas got several good looks early that wouldn't fall. The
Jayhawks missed 17 of their first 20 shots and shot 26.7 percent in
the first half. Collison was 1-for-9 at the break.

	   Hinrich, who fouled out with 1:20 left, had just one field goal
in the first 15 minutes. He hit three baskets in the final 4:45 but
it wasn't much help -- his last basket, a 3-pointer, only got the
Jayhawks within 16 on their way to a 21-point halftime deficit.
